column1: Buckeye is a city in Maricopa County
column3: and is the westernmost suburb in the Phoenix metropolitan area. The US Census estimates the population to be 79
column4: 620 as of 2019.  It was the fastest-growing city in the United States for both 2017 and 2018.

column15: Watson Road is the site of the city's commercial center.In 2008

column1: Buckeye is located approximately 30 miles (48 km) west of downtown Phoenix.

column1: Buckeye has a hot desert climate (Köppen BWh)
column2: with abundant sunshine due to the stable descending air of the eastern side of the subtropical anticyclone aloft and at sea level over the southwestern United States. Summers
column3: as with most of the Sonoran Desert
column5: with 121.0 afternoons reaching 100 °F or 37.8 °C and 181.6 afternoons reaching 90 °F or 32.2 °C. The record high temperature of 128 °F (53.3 °C) occurred on July 28
column7: and temperatures above 86 °F or 30 °C may occur in any month. Cooler weather may occasionally occur during summer
column8: but such periods are no less unpleasant as they result from monsoonal weather
column9: with its attendant higher cloudiness and humidity; however
column10: actual rainfall from the monsoon is much more infrequent than in Flagstaff
column11: Nogales or even Tucson. The heaviest daily rainfall has been 4.90 inches (124.5 mm) on September 2
column13: but between 1971 and 2000 no month had more rainfall than 4.52 inches or 114.8 millimetres in December 1984.

column1: The winter season from November to March is warm to very warm during the day
column2: not much cooler than 68 °F or 20 °C during a typical afternoon
column3: but 20.2 mornings typically fall to or below 32 °F or 0 °C
column4: though no snowfall was recorded during the 1971 to 2000 period
column5: and only twelve afternoons did not reach 50 °F or 10 °C. The coldest temperature recorded in Buckeye was 11 °F or −11.7 °C on January 8

column1: Buckeye first appeared on the 1910 U.S. Census as a precinct of Maricopa County. It appeared again in 1920 as the 48th precinct of Maricopa County (Buckeye). It incorporated as a town in 1929 and has appeared on every successive census. On January 1
column3: Buckeye was upgraded to city status.In 2015
column4: the population of the city was 62
column9: 499 households in the city. The population density was 135.6 people per square mile (17.3/km2). There were 18
column10: 207 housing units. 10.8% of the population were born overseas.

column3: with 9.1% under the age of 5; 30.6% under the age of 18; 53% aged between 18 and 64 and 6.7% were 65 years of age or older. 45.4% percent of the population are women.

column1: A popular recreation destination in Buckeye is the Buckeye Hills Recreation Area. It is located 7 miles (11 km) south of downtown Buckeye on State Route 85
column2: at mile marker 144. A 900-acre (3.6 km2) Buckeye Lake is planned.

column1: The City of Buckeye's Skyline Regional Park is an 8
column3: 500 ha) mountain preserve located in the southern White Tank Mountains. As of August 2020
column4: the park features just under 20 miles (32 km) of trails for hikers
column6: picnic areas and camping. Entry to the park is free.

column2: the Arizona Eastern Railroad came to Buckeye; the first car in 1911; a steam rail line connected it to Phoenix by 1912; and a state highway by 1915. The coming of the railroad was so significant that the business district was moved to accommodate the location of the railroad station. As a result
column5: along with expansion of the business community.Union Pacific operates a rail line running east–west generally through the center of the city.

column1: The Buckeye Municipal Airport (ICAO identifier KBXK) is owned and operated by the city government.
